stem: The nurse is preparing to perform tracheostomy suctioning for a client with copious secretions. Place the following steps in the correct order of priority.

options.text: Insert the suction catheter without applying suction until resistance is met or the client coughs.
Apply intermittent suction while rotating and withdrawing the catheter over no more than 10-15 seconds.
Re-oxygenate the client and allow for a rest period between suction passes.
Assess the client's lung sounds, oxygen saturation, and heart rate.

rationale.correct: The correct order prioritizes client safety and effective secretion removal while minimizing complications. Hyper-oxygenating with 100% FiO2 (o1) before suctioning creates an oxygen reserve to prevent suction-induced hypoxemia. Inserting the catheter without suction (o2) minimizes trauma to the tracheal mucosa. Applying intermittent suction while rotating and withdrawing (o3) effectively removes secretions without prolonged mucosal contact, limiting each pass to 10-15 seconds to prevent hypoxia. Re-oxygenating and allowing rest (o4) between suction passes allows the client to recover and prevents desaturation. Assessing lung sounds, oxygen saturation, and heart rate (o5) evaluates the effectiveness of the suctioning and identifies any adverse effects.
rationale.incorrect: Failing to hyper-oxygenate increases the risk of hypoxemia. Applying suction during insertion can damage the tracheal lining. Omitting rest periods can lead to client fatigue and desaturation. Assessing the client before intervening does not address the immediate need for airway clearance. Each step is crucial for safe and effective tracheostomy suctioning.
answerBreakdown: o1: Correct. Hyper-oxygenation is crucial to prevent hypoxemia during suctioning.
o2: Correct. Inserting without suction prevents mucosal damage.
o3: Correct. Intermittent suction and rotation effectively remove secretions while minimizing trauma and hypoxia.
o4: Correct. Re-oxygenation and rest prevent desaturation and fatigue.
o5: Correct. Assessment evaluates effectiveness and identifies adverse effects.
clinicalPearls: Suction pressure should be set between 80-120 mmHg for adults to avoid mucosal damage. Monitor the client's SpO2 and heart rate closely during the procedure. Limit each suction pass to 10-15 seconds to minimize hypoxia. Use sterile technique to prevent infection. Observe for signs of respiratory distress or vagal stimulation (bradycardia) during the procedure.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Always remember: Never apply suction when inserting the catheter. Applying suction during insertion can cause significant trauma to the delicate tracheal mucosa, leading to bleeding and potential long-term damage. Visualize the catheter gently gliding into the trachea without any abrasive force. Only apply suction during withdrawal.

mnemonic.title: H-I-S-R-A
mnemonic.expansion: Hyper-oxygenate, Insert (no suction), Suction (intermittent), Re-oxygenate/Rest, Assess.

reviewUnits.heading: Airway Management: Tracheostomy Care and Suctioning
reviewUnits.body: Nurses must use sterile technique for open suctioning to prevent ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). Monitor for bradycardia during the procedure, which indicates vagal stimulation. Vagal stimulation can lead to a sudden drop in heart rate and blood pressure, requiring immediate intervention such as stopping the suctioning and administering oxygen. Ensure proper catheter size to prevent airway obstruction. Pre-oxygenate with 100% FiO2 for at least 30 seconds before suctioning.

itemContext.sbar:
Situation: Client with tracheostomy and copious secretions requiring suctioning.
Background: Client has a tracheostomy due to [underlying condition]. Currently exhibiting increased work of breathing and audible rhonchi. Last suctioning was at [time]. Baseline SpO2 is [percentage] on [FiO2].
Assessment: Current SpO2 is [percentage] on [FiO2]. Heart rate is [beats per minute]. Lung sounds reveal coarse rhonchi bilaterally. Client is restless and appears uncomfortable. Increased respiratory rate.
Recommendation: Recommend immediate tracheostomy suctioning to clear airway secretions and improve oxygenation. Monitor SpO2 and heart rate closely during and after the procedure. Consider increasing frequency of suctioning if secretions remain excessive. Assess for signs of infection.
